selection_rationale: Under non-IID label skew, client drift is amplified by long local training and sparse aggregation. Increasing client_fraction strengthens averaging across diverse label distributions, reducing drift. Reducing local_steps limits local overfitting to skewed labels. Momentum in SFedAvg controls how projected gradients accumulate; tuning mu can damp oscillations and improve stability with skew.

configs.rationale: More clients per round with fewer local steps increases aggregation frequency and reduces drift; keeps strong SFedAvg momentum to smooth updates.
Aggressive drift control via short local training; slightly lower mu to avoid overshooting under skew.
Moderate aggregation, short local steps, stronger mu to leverage projected momentum for faster convergence while monitoring stability.
Minimal change to aggregation, primarily cut local drift; baseline mu to isolate the effect of tau reduction.
High aggregation with baseline local steps; tests whether broader averaging alone stabilizes skewed updates.
Stress long local training with more clients to see if increased aggregation compensates for drift; useful to contrast FedAvg vs SFedAvg stability.
Balanced aggregation and local work; slightly lower mu to reduce potential oscillations while maintaining smoothing.

expected_improvement: Compared to baseline, configurations with higher client_fraction (0.4–0.6) and fewer local_steps (2–4) should yield smoother loss, 1–3% higher test accuracy, reduced oscillations, and potentially fewer rounds to reach target accuracy, with SFedAvg benefitting most from tuned momentum.
